Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: VocaliD - Infusing Unique Vocal Identities into Synthesized Speech
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to offer custom crafted digital voices for text-to-speech applications. Each one of us has a unique voiceprint - an essential part of our self-identity. Though the quality of text-to-speech technology has improved, voice options remain limited. For the 2.5 million Americans (and tens of millions worldwide) living with voicelessness who rely on devices to talk, access to a custom digital voice is a game changer. It's the difference between a functional solution and being heard, uniquely, as oneself. Enhanced opportunities for social connection increase quality of life, independence, and access to educational and vocational resources that can narrow the gap between those with and without disability. This immediate unmet societal need, coupled with the increasing proliferation of devices that speak to us and for us, creates a compelling, timely and significant commercial opportunity for high quality, personalized digital voices that can be produced at scale. By leveraging the company's crowdsourced human voicebank and proprietary voice matching and blending algorithms the technology has the potential to empower everyone to express themselves through their own voice.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project builds on the company's NSF-funded research and Phase I results that support feasibility and commercialization of a customized voice building technology. The text-to-speech market, encompassing assistive technologies, enterprise and consumer applications, is currently valued at around $1B and is rapidly growing and ripe for innovation. To create custom voices, the company leverages the source-filter theory of speech production. From those who are unable or unwilling to record several hours of speech the company extracts a brief vocal sample - even a single vowel contains enough 'vocal DNA' to seed the personalization process. Identity cues of the source are then combined with filter properties of a demographically and acoustically matched donor in the company's voicebank. The result is a voice that captures the vocal identity of the recipient but the clarity of the donor. Phase II technical objectives address the need for 1) customer-driven voice customization, 2) quality assurance of crowdsourced recordings, 3) voice aging algorithms, and 4) targeted donor recruitment algorithms. These advances will help secure the assistive technology beachhead and spur innovations for broader applications such as virtual reality, personal robotics, and digital persona for the Internet of Things.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although communication devices are getting smarter and using more sophisticated language, digital voices today continue to be either low-quality and robotic (e.g. parking garage kiosk) or cost millions of dollars to manufacture (e.g. Siri, Alexa). A one-size-fits-all solution is a missed market opportunity in a world of increasing personalization and human-machine integration. Conventional voice building methods require a voice actor to complete an extensive dataset of studio-quality recordings to train and generate a synthetic voice. The process is time and labor intensive and thus inaccessible to small businesses or everyday consumers such as 2.5 million American with severe speech impairments who rely on text-to-speech (TTS) applications to communicate. VocaliD’s personalized TTS voices are made using only a brief sample of the recipient’s residual vocalizations combined with recordings of a matched speaker from our crowdsourced Human Voicebank. We discovered that even a single vowel contains enough "vocal DNA" to seed the personalization process. A VocaliD custom voice sounds like the recipient in age, personality and vocal identity but is as clear and understandable as the donor’s recordings. Over 28,000 voice donors ranging in age from 6-91 from 110 countries have collectively contributed over 13.6 Million sentences to our Voicebank. This data asset along with our proprietary voice matching and blending algorithms provide a distinct competitive advantage to create more inclusive and representative synthetic voices for individuals and organizations.

Intellectual merit: This SBIR Phase II focused on improving the efficiency and adoption of VocaliD’s custom voice building innovation from both technical and business perspectives. Specifically, while Phase I results showed that our personalized voices resembled the recipient, they also revealed that clarity and naturalness warranted further development. Furthermore, Phase I early adopters indicated a desire to modify their voice based on preferences and needs. This critical insight that preference was as important as voice accuracy sparked additional research and product development. Last, in order for customers to utilize the voices for daily communication, our technology needed to be integrated into existing assistive communication devices. We also built our own mobile application as part of this Phase II project. In addition to our technological advances, we formed partnerships with leading assistive communication device manufacturers to integrate our voice engine within their applications and to serve as resellers and/or channel partners. 

Broader Implications: VocaliD's custom voices empower those users of TTS to be heard as themselves. Not only do recipients benefit, but family members can connect with their loved ones at an entirely new level; teachers can differentiate among their students who rely on assistive devices to communicate; and strangers can hear a glimmer of personality hidden behind the device. These opportunities for social connection, increase independence, and access to educational and vocational resources, can narrow the gap between those with and without disability. Today, VocaliD is the flagship brand for personalized voices for those living with speechlessness. Over 300 individuals are now using their VocaliD voice over the past 5 years. VocaliD's Human Voicebank and advanced technology infrastructure also open up new market opportunities in customer support and audio content generation. With increasing reliance on speech interfaces for automated assistants, social robots, and the 'internet of things', the demand for personalized TTS is skyrocketing. VocaliD harnesses the power of digital voice to enhance how we learn, work, play and live.
